title: 114_s1723
content: The Act titled "Promoting Renewable Energy with Shared Solar Act of 2015" provides interconnection service and net billing service for community solar facilities. The Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 is amended to include definitions for community solar facilities, which are solar systems that allocate electricity to multiple consumers, have a rating of 2 megawatts or less, and are owned by the electric utility. The term 'interconnection service' refers to a service provided by an electric utility to connect a community solar facility to a local distribution facility, whether owned by the utility, jointly owned, or third-party-owned, and located on or off the property of a consumer of the electricity. The community solar facility is connected to a local distribution facility through net billing service provided by an electric utility to offset energy usage. Electric utilities must make this service available upon request from consumers. Electric utilities must provide interconnection service and net billing service for a community solar facility. State regulatory authorities and nonregulated utilities have specific time limitations to consider the standards set by the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978. Each State regulatory authority and nonregulated electric utility must complete consideration and make a determination regarding the standards set by the Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978 within a specified timeframe. Failure to comply may result in penalties as outlined in the Act. The text chunk discusses the establishment of standards by paragraphs (15), (16), and (20) of section 111(d) in relation to the date of enactment of the Act. It also includes a technical correction regarding the references to the enactment dates. The text chunk addresses a technical correction in Section 1254(b) of the Energy Policy Act of 2005, specifically striking paragraph (2) and voiding an amendment made by paragraph (2). It also mentions the effect of prior state actions. The text addresses a technical correction in Section 1254(b) of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 by voiding an amendment made by paragraph (2) and mentioning the impact of prior state actions on the implementation of standards for electric utilities. The State legislature's vote on implementing a standard for electric utilities is addressed in the text, with a technical correction made to Section 124 of the Public Utility Regulatory Policy Act of 1978.
